prompt:
PATIENT: 67 F
INDICATION: abnormal chest imaging
PROCEDURE: Bronchoscopy w/ Biopsy
FINDINGS: scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis, minimal narrowing
SPECIMEN: Subglottic endobronchial biopsies
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_081 SOURCE_FILE: note_081.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 67-year-old female who presents with abnormal chest imaging.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field.

Subglottic scarring/stenosis.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None.

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis.
There was minimal narrowing at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the subglottic level.
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

Subglottic endobronchial biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

67-year-old female presented for bronchoscopy for abnormal chest imaging.

Airway inspection revealed scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis with minimal narrowing;
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

Subglottic lesion successfully biopsied and removed.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

prompt: Please draft an operative note for a 20-year-old female presenting with persistent wheezing. We performed a therapeutic aspiration and diagnostic bronchoscopy. Findings included thick secretions throughout the bronchial tree with mild dynamic airway collapse. We took biopsies from the distal trachea (surveillance).

prompt: 53yo M with hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy showed a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus. Did aspiration and bx of RUL bronchus. Dx: Endobronchial lesion RUL.

NOTE_ID: note_081 SOURCE_FILE: note_081.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 53-year-old male who presents with hemoptysis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D14.3 Benign neoplasm of bronchus and lung.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D14.3 Benign neoplasm of bronchus and lung.

Endobronchial lesion RUL.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None.

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus.
There was partial obstruction of the RUL orifice at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the RUL bronchus.
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

RUL endobronchial biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

53-year-old male presented for bronchoscopy for hemoptysis.

Airway inspection revealed a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus with partial obstruction of the RUL orifice;
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

RUL lesion biopsied.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 29-year-old female who presents with persistent wheezing.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J38.6 Stenosis of larynx.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J38.6 Stenosis of larynx.

Tracheal stenosis.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for circumferential narrowing at the proximal trachea.
There was moderate narrowing (~50%) at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the proximal trachea.
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

Tracheal tissue biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

29-year-old female presented for bronchoscopy for persistent wheezing.

Airway inspection revealed circumferential narrowing at the proximal trachea with moderate narrowing (~50%);
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

Tracheal stenosis dilated and biopsied.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

NOTE_ID: note_081 SOURCE_FILE: note_081.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 73-year-old male who presents with persistent wheezing.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J38.6 Stenosis of larynx.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J38.6 Stenosis of larynx.

Tracheal stenosis.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None.

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for circumferential narrowing at the proximal trachea.
There was moderate narrowing (~50%) at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the proximal trachea.
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

Tracheal tissue biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

73-year-old male presented for bronchoscopy for persistent wheezing.

Airway inspection revealed circumferential narrowing at the proximal trachea with moderate narrowing (~50%);
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

Tracheal stenosis dilated and biopsied.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

prompt: Please draft an operative note for a 46-year-old female presenting with chronic cough. We performed a therapeutic aspiration and diagnostic bronchoscopy. Findings included scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis with minimal narrowing. We took biopsies from the subglottic level.
completion:

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

R91.8 Other nonspecific abnormal finding of lung field.

Subglottic scarring/stenosis.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.

Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis.
There was minimal narrowing at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the subglottic level.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

Subglottic endobronchial biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

46-year-old female presented for bronchoscopy for chronic cough.

Airway inspection revealed scarring at the subglottic space, the previous site of stenosis with minimal narrowing;
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

Subglottic lesion successfully biopsied and removed.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 22-year-old female who presents with dyspnea.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J44.9 Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J44.9 Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Mucous plugging.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None.

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for thick secretions throughout the bronchial tree.
There was mild dynamic airway collapse at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the distal trachea (surveillance).
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

Distal tracheal biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

22-year-old female presented for bronchoscopy for dyspnea.

Airway inspection revealed thick secretions throughout the bronchial tree with mild dynamic airway collapse;
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

Mucous plugs cleared via aspiration.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.

prompt: 32yo M with stridor. Bronchoscopy showed a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus. Did aspiration and bx of RUL bronchus. Dx: Endobronchial lesion RUL.
completion:
NOTE_ID: note_081 SOURCE_FILE: note_081.txt

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 32-year-old male who presents with stridor.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits, and alternatives to bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

Consent Status: The patient wished to proceed and informed consent was obtained.
Discussion: Risks, benefits, and alternatives were discussed in detail.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D14.3 Benign neoplasm of bronchus and lung.
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

D14.3 Benign neoplasm of bronchus and lung.

Endobronchial lesion RUL.

PROCEDURE

Therapeutic aspiration (initial episode).

Diagnostic bronchoscopy with cell washing.
Endobronchial biopsy(s).

ANESTHESIA Monitored Anesthesia Care (MAC).

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None.

COMPLICATIONS None.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Initial Airway Inspection The airway was inspected. The vocal cords were normal appearing.
Lidocaine was applied to the vocal cords and the airway.
Findings: The airway anatomy was notable for a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus.
There was partial obstruction of the RUL orifice at this site. The remainder of the airway was normal appearing to the segmental level bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out mucus from the following segments:

Vocal Cord

Subglottic

Trachea (Proximal 1/3, Middle 1/3, Distal 1/3)

Right Mainstem

Bronchus Intermedius

Left Mainstem

Carina

RUL Carina (RC1)

RML Carina (RC2)

LUL Lingula Carina (Lc1)

Left Carina (LC2)

Endobronchial Biopsy Endobronchial biopsy was performed at the RUL bronchus.
The lesion was successfully removed. Samples were sent for Pathology.

Conclusion The patient tolerated the procedure well.
There were no immediate complications. At the conclusion of the operation, the patient was extubated in the operating room and transported to the recovery room in stable condition.
SPECIMEN(S)

RUL endobronchial biopsies.

IMPRESSION/PLAN

32-year-old male presented for bronchoscopy for stridor.

Airway inspection revealed a polypoid lesion within the Right Upper Lobe bronchus with partial obstruction of the RUL orifice;
remainder of airway normal.

Therapeutic aspiration performed for mucus clearance across multiple segments.

RUL lesion biopsied.
Plan: Follow-up bronchoscopic lab work.
